> Tracing the allocation chain in the original version 
> (targeted at 1.3) showed this distribution of allocations:
>  %   in
> ---  ------ 
> 44%  junit.textui.ResultPrinter.elapsedTimeAsString()
> 2.5% junit.textui.ResultPrinter.printeDefect()
> 2.5% junit.textui.TestRunner.createTestResult()
> 2.0% junit.textui.TestRunner.junit.textui.TestRunner()
>      (huh????)

what's strange is that the 'elapsedTimeAsString' method is only invoked _once_
(at the end of the run, to display the duration of the run).  So I don't
understand how 44% of the allocations are made inside a method that is only
invoked once.

> Similarly, out of 1624 strings allocated, for 80K,
> 51% were in junit.textui.ResultPrinter.elapsedTimeAsString()
> (the numbers are probably related)

the method only executes:

   NumberFormat.getInstance().format((double) runTime/1000);

and it's exactly how the NumberFormat should be used (see javadoc
documentation).

What I would do is recompile JUnit and only return "" for the elapsedTime and
see if it fixes some of your problems.

-Vladimir
